illustration.illusobjdesc: The Spirit of Peace descends over the Nativity scene, awakening the slumbering Nature below. The Spirit of Peace is presented as a personified bird or angel, and flies upside down above the stable on outstretched wings. Right of the manger, the Virgin Mary kneels on a small mound of straw and holds the sleeping infant Christ in her arms. Joseph stands to the right and leans over the pair. To the left, two horned cows eat from the manger. Below the scene, the Spirit of Nature lays on her side and is seen from behind, with her hands together in prayer. The ground below the stable is covered in indeterminate vegetation. Clouds appear left and right of the stable's roof, and cirlces of light or radience appears behind the Spirit of Peace.

component.illusobjdesc: In the top half of the design, the Spirit of Peace descends as a personified bird or angel over the Nativity scene, awakening the slumbering Nature below. She is gowned and flies or hovers on outstretched wings. She is upside down and faces left, with her torso bent downward. Her arms are spread apart, with her right arm raised horizontally (relative to her body) and her left raised at 135 degrees. Her right palm is turned out with the fingers spread, while in her left hand she grasps a stick or staff. She has long hair and wears a crown or wreath of vines on her head.
The Spirit of Peace holds a long stick or staff with a leafy vine coiled around it.

Near the center of the design, the Virgin Mary kneels on a mound of straw and faces forward and to the left. She is gowned and wears a cloth veil or scarf over her long hair. Her head is surrounded by a small halo of light. Her arms are folded on her lap as she holds the infant Christ. Her head is bent down and to the left, and she appears to look at the infant in her arms. Her left foot is prominent as it extends beyond the hem of her garment.
The Virgin Mary kneels on a small mound of straw. The floor of the stable is also covered in straw.

Joseph stands just to the right of the Virgin Mary, facing left. He is bent forward slightly so that he leans over Mary and Christ, and seems to look at the infant. He wears a gown and has curly hair and a beard. A small halo of light surrounds his head. He stands with his arms down at his sides. His left foot is visible beneath the hem of his garment.

Mary holds the infant Christ in her arms. He is swaddled in a cloth or drapery of some sort. His eyes are closed, and he may be sleeping. There are indications of curly hair at his temples, and a halo with spiky lines of radience. He faces forward, upward, and turns slightly toward the right.

At the bottom of the design, the Spirit of Nature, personified as a nude female, wakes and looks up towards the Spirit of Peace. She lays on her side and is seen from behind, with her right arm resting on the ground with her palms together as though in prayer. Her legs are crossed at the ankles. She is nude, but is partially covered by earth or vegetation around her buttocks.

The Nativity scene takes place in a wooden stable with a clearly defined floor, roof, posts, and beams. The figures are framed by a pointed gothic arch below the crown of the roof. The stable is viewed as though in cross section, a perspective that may suggest a window. Nails are visible on the side posts and the manger; the head of one nail appears on the back wall.
Two horned cows or oxen stand to left of the Virgin Mary and eat straw or hay from a manger.
The cows eat hay or straw from a manger.
The ground below the stable is covered in indeterminate vegetation, possibly including grass. Some of the vegetation extends over the buttocks of the awakening Spirit of Nature.
Bands of clouds are pictured left and right of the stable's roof.
The stone-like objects that fill the margins left and right of the stable may actually represent vegetation covered in frost, snow, or sleet.
Light or radiance appears as three concentric circles behind the Spirit of Peace, possibly emmanating from the Star of Bethlehem.

lg.l: WBlake 18The inscription, particularly the date (presumably "1809"), is partly trimmed off the sheet.

desc.objtitle: The Annunciation to the Shepherds, Object 2 (Butlin 538.2)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A group of six shepherds sit or kneel below a host of angels. All of the shepherds are gowned and some also wear cloaks or shawls with hoods. The figure third from the left is a small child. He pets a dog. The central figure (fourth from the left) has his hands raised with the fingers spread. The old, bearded figure immediately to the right kneels with his hands together as if in prayer. The rightmost figure, bearded and wearing a hood, also clasps his hands in prayer or awe. A large flock of sheep extends to the group's left and right. The sheep appear to be lying down, and many of them may be sleeping. The host of angels consists of five winged males (presumably Cherubim) in the center with eight females (Seraphim?) in a circle around them. The central males are gowned, wear large hats, helmets, or crowns, and have swords at their sides. Each stands with arms raised at 135 degrees with their arms overlapping. Two of the figures (second and fourth from the left) have beards. Six of the angels in the circle hold and play instruments, including four harps, a lyre, and a mandolin or lute. Several of the angels have their mouths open and they may be singing. Beams of light or radiance surround the host of angels. A distant view of the Nativity is show between the shepherds and the angels. The stable is shown with a large deocrative archway through which we see the Virgin Mary kneeling or sitting on the ground with Joseph standing to the right. Though unclear, it is possible that Mary holds the infant Christ in her arms.

component.illusobjdesc: A group of shepherds appears at the bottom of the design. Furthest left, a male shepherd sits or kneels facing right. He is gowned and wears a cloak with a hood. His hair is curly, and he looks up toward the group of angels above.

A group of shepherds appears at the bottom of the design. Second from the left, a male shepherd kneels facing right. He is gowned and wears a hooded cloak or scarf over his long curly hair. He looks up toward the group of angels above. His right arm is extended with the fingers on his right hand spread. He may be touching the dog to the right.

A male child stands(?) third from the left in the group of shepherds. Only his head, upper body, and left arm are visible. He wears a gown or shirt and has (long?) curly hair. He faces forward and looks at the figure to the left. His left arm is raised horizontallyt and slightly bent at the elbow; his left hand is resting on the head of the dog to the right.

A group of shepherds appears at the bottom of the design. Fourth from the left, a male shepherd sits on a stone and faces away from the viewer, but with his head turned to the left in profile. He is gowned and possibly wears a cloak; he has curly hair. His head is bent back as he looks up toward the group of angels above. His arms are bent upward with both hands raised with the palms out and fingers spread. His legs are bent with the right leg extended backward. His mouth may be slightly open and he may be wearing a shoe or sandal on his prominent right foot (his left foot appears to be bare).

A group of shepherds appears at the bottom of the design. Fifth from the left, an old male shepherd kneels facing left. He wears a gown or cloak and has long hair and a beard. He appears hunched over and kneels on his left knee with his right leg drawn up. His arms are bent and his hands are together in prayer, with fingers slightly spread. He looks up toward the group of angels above.

A group of shepherds appears at the bottom of the design. Furthest right, an old male shepherd sits (on a stone?) facing left. He wears a gown and a cloak with the hood over his head. He has a long beard and his mouth is slightly open. He looks up toward the group of angels above. His hands are clasped together in prayer.
The shepherds first and third from the right sit on rectangular objects, possibly large stones.
A dog stands, faces left in profile, between the third and fourth figures from the left in the group of shepherds.

A large flock of sheep extends to the left and right of the group of shepherds. They all appear to be lying down, and some are possibly sleeping. Most are indistinct masses, but at least five have distinct heads (three are pictured to the left of the group of figures, one between the fourth and fifth figures from the left, and one to the far right of the group of figures). Three of these sheep face left; the leftmost has its head down while the rightmost has its head up. The two other sheep near the left margin face right.

Above the shepherds, five winged angels stand or hover in a row. The first angel from the left is gowned and wears a hat, helmet or crown, possibly surmounted with feathers. Indications of a sword hang from his left hip. His left arm is raised at 135 degrees with the palm out towards the viewer; his right arm is not clearly pictured. The body of this figure is facing forward and slightly to the left, but his head is turned to face right.

Above the shepherds, five winged angels stand or hover in a row. The second figure from the left is gowned and wears a hat, helemt, or possibly a crown decorated with feathers. The figure is bearded and there may be a belt at his waist. Indications of a sword hang from his left hip. Both arms are raised at 135 degrees with the palms out towards the viewer. His right arm crosses in front of the figure to the left, while his left arm is pictured behind the figure to the right. The figure faces forward with his right leg and foot prominent.

Above the shepherds, five winged angels stand or hover in a row. The third figure from the left is gowned and wears a hat, helemt, or possibly a crown decorated with feathers. Indications of a sword hang from his left hip. There may be a belt at his waist. A belt or sash appears to run from the middle of the figure's chest to his right hip. Both arms are raised at 135 degrees with the palms out towards the viewer. His right arm crosses in front of the figure to the left, while his left arm is pictured behind the figure to the right. The figure faces forward with his left leg and foot prominent.

Above the shepherds, five winged angels stand or hover in a row. The fourth figure from the left is gowned and wears a hat, helmet, or possibly a crown decorated with feathers. The figure is bearded. Indications of a sword hang from his left hip. A belt or sash appears to run from the figure's right shoulder to his left hip. Both arms are raised at 135 degrees with the palms out towards the viewer. Both arms are pictured in front of the figures to his left and right. The figure faces forward with his left leg and foot prominent.

Above the shepherds, five winged angels stand or hover in a row. The fifth figure from the left is gowned and wears a hat, helemt, or possibly a crown. Indications of a sword hang from his left hip. Both arms appear to be raised at 135 degrees, but only the figure's right hand is shown with the palm out towards the viewer. The figure faces slightly to the right with his head turned up.

A circle of eight female angels flies or hovers around the five male angels. The angel at the bottom left of the circle is gowned and has long hair. Her body is horizontal and her gown mingles with the gown of the angel to the right. The figure holds—and likely plays—a harp. The figure bends her left arm to hold or play the instrument. She faces left with her head turned back to the right. Her mouth appears to be slightly open and she may be signing.

A circle of eight female angels flies or hovers around the five male angels. The angel at the bottom right of the circle is gowned and has long hair. Her body is horizontal and her gown mingles with that of the angel to the left. The figure holds—and likely plays—a harp. The figure bends her right arm to hold or play the instrument. She faces right with her head turned back to the left. The figure may be smiling.

A circle of eight female angels flies or hovers around the five male angels. The angel second from the bottom left is gowned and may have her hair drawn back into a bun. She is seen from behind and faces to the left with her head tilted upwards. Her left arm is bent. She is probably holding and playing a large harp or lyre, the left outline of which is visible to the left of the figure.

A circle of eight female angels flies or hovers around the five male angels. The angel second from the bottom right is gowned and faces to the right with her head tilted upwards. Her left arm is bent and she holds—and likely plays—a stringed instrument, possibly a lyre. There is the suggestion that her left arm is also bent to play the instrument, though this is less clear.

A circle of eight female angels flies or hovers around the five male angels. The angel third from the bottom left is gowned and faces right. The figure's right arm is bent to hold or play a mandolin or lute. Her left arm is not pictured clearly, but may bend upward towards the neck of the instrument. Her mouth appears to be open slightly and she may be singing.

A circle of eight female angels flies or hovers around the five male angels. The angel third from the bottom right is gowned and has long hair. The figure's left arm is bent to hold or play a harp. The figure's mouth is open and she may be singing. She faces forward and to the left.

A circle of eight female angels flies or hovers around five male angels. The angel at the top left of the circle is gowned and possibly has long hair. She is seen from behind and her body arches to the right with at least one arm (her right) extended towards the figure to the right. Her extended arm covers her face.

A circle of eight female angels flies or hovers around five male angels. The angel at the top right of the circle is gowned and possibly has long hair. She is seen from behind and her body arches to the left with at least one arm (her left) extended towards the figure to the left.

Beams of light or radience emanate from the host of angels. Within the circle, washes below and between the standing male angels suggest fire. Dark coloring on the outer edges of the beams of light suggest darkness or a night scene.
The stable is pictured below the host of angels with a clearly visible roof (made of straw?) and a decorative Gothic arch. The walls of the structure extend left and right of the open archway.

The Virgin Mary is pictured in the archway of the stable, kneeling or sitting on the floor. It is possible that she holds the infant Christ in her arms, although this is not clearly represented. She probably wears a gown.
Joseph stands to the right of the Virgin Mary in the manger. He is gowned and bends left towards Mary.
Small hills rise to the left and right of the stable. A larger hill or mountain rises near the right margin.

Coloring and a few lines below the stable and the shepherds suggest grass. Indeterminate vegetation, possibly bushes or small trees, may cover the ground between the stable and the group of shepherds.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The top third of the design shows the Nativity scene. The Virgin Mary (right) and Joseph (left) are pictured through a large archway in the stable. Both figures are kneeling and Mary holds the infant Christ in her arms. Joseph may be praying. Outside the stable, two winged angels stand flanking the archway. They may also be praying. A flock of sheep lies to the left and right of the archway. They seem to be sleeping. Dark wash indicates a night scene, and a trail of fifteen stars arches over the stable. Grass covers the ground below. The lower half of the design depicts the "old Dragon" of Milton's poem and eleven other figures in a large cave-like hollow underground. The dragon (possibly Typhon), the six-headed figure, sits with his legs drawn up and crossed at the ankles. Several of his heads look up toward the Nativity scene. Four heads have beards, and three or four of these appear to also have horns. The dragon's right arm is bent and his elbow rests on a rock to the left. He holds a large scepter in his right hand. His left arm is bent upward and wraps around his heads. His left palm is held vertically with the fingers slightly spread. A large serpent or dragon tail encircles the figure and extends upward to the right of the stable. Moving clockwise, a nude male is seen from behind to the right of multi-headed dragon. He appears to be running or leaping to the right, and he clutches he head with both hands. A nude male with scales covering his genitals crouches below the leaping figure. His left arm is raised at 135 degrees and points upward. His head is turned slightly to the left and he wears an expression of fear. To the left, a nude male kneels on the ground and leans on the rock to the left with his left elbow. The figure is seen from behind with his head is bent back and turned to the right. His right arm is raised vertically with his palm up and the fingers of his right hand spread. To the left, a bald nude male sits with his left leg drawn up and his right leg extended below and to the right. His arms are bent and crossed loosely in front of his chest. His head is bent back and turned towards the right. He may hold the hilt of a sword with his left hand. The sword rests on the ground to the left of the figure alongside a round shield decorated with blots of lightning. To the left of the bald figure is a smiling male holding a dagger in his right hand. Above this is an old male with long hair and a beard. His right arm is raised vertically and he holds a bag of coins in his right hand. Above this figure are two disembodied heads with long hair. They may be female. To the right of these figures is a seated old woman with short hair. She is partly nude with her breasts exposed and a skirt or gown covering her legs. Her legs are drawn up and crossed at the ankles with her left foot prominent. Her head is bent back and turned to the right, and she may be looking toward the Nativity scene above. Both arms are bent and she may be clutching the sides of her head. To her right is the upper body of a nude female. She has long hair and scales cover her torso below her breasts. Above this is the head of another figure with only the eyes and nose visible. The figures in the lower portion of the design are surrounded by flames.

component.illusobjdesc: The stable is shown in the upper half of the design. The roof may be made of straw, and the walls left and right of the archway appear to be wooden. In the center is a pointed Gothic arch.

The Virgin Mary is pictured in the stable. She is gowned and kneels facing left. She may wear a cloth mantle or scarf over her long hair. In her arms she holds the infant Christ. Her head is turned down slightly towards the child.
Joseph kneels to the left of the Virgin Mary. He faces right in profile with his arms bent. He may have his hands together as if in prayer.

Two angels with large wings stand flanking the stable's arched entry. Both figures are gowned. The figure on the left faces left while the figure on the right faces right. Both have a single arm visible which is bent with the palm held vertically as if in prayer.
A flock of sheep lies on the ground to either side of the stable's arched entry. The sheep appear to be sleeping. Those on the left face left; those on the right face right.
The ground below the stable is covered with vegetation, probably grass.
Dark sky above and to the left and right of the stable indicates a night scene. A trail of stars—perhaps fifteen in all—arches above the stable.

The lower half of the design is an underground scene, with figures set within a cave-like space formed, at least in part, by large stones. Coloring throughout (but particularly in the top left and bottom right) suggests flames.

The central figure in the lower portion of the design is the "old Dragon" of Milton's poem, possibly represented here as Typhon. The figure has six heads, faces forward, and sits cross-legged on a large stone or outcrop with his prominent kneed drawn up to his chest. His right arm is bent and its elbow rests on a rock. In his right hand he holds a scepter with a fleur-de-lis (and pomegranate?) finial. His left arm is bent upward and wraps around three of his his heads. A large serpent or dragon tail with scales encircles the figure and extends upward to the right of the stable. He appears to be nude and his bare feet are prominent.

The upper left head of the multi-headed dragon is tilted up with its eyes raised and mouth slightly open. He has short curly hair and wears an expression of fear or concern. He appears to look toward the Nativity scene above.

The upper central head of the multi-headed dragon is tilted up with its eyes raised. He has a beard, long hair, and possibly two curved horns protruding from either side of his head. He appears to look toward the Nativity scene above.

The upper right head of the multi-headed dragon is bent back and faces left in profile. His eyes are raised and he appears to look toward the Nativity scene above. The prominent round form on his forehead may be hair or a horn.
The lower left head of the multi-headed dragon faces forward. He is bearded and he may have two horn-like protrusions on either side of his head.

The lower central head of the multi-headed dragon faces forward with its eyes cast down, as though he were looking deeper into the cave or pit. He has long hair and a beard. Two small horns erupt at his hairline just above his temples. There are indications of a small crown resting on top of his head. His expression suggests surprise or fear.
The lower right head of the multi-headed dragon is bent back and faces left and up. He has long hair and a beard. His eyes are raised and he appears to look toward the Nativity scene above.

To the right of the multi-headed dragon, a nude male with wavy or curly hair is seen from behind. The figure's body is twisted and faces away from the viewer, with his head bent back in left profile. The figure leaps or runs to the right with his legs spread and his right leg extended backward. The figure's right arm is bent (his left is not visible), and both hands appear to clutch the sides of his head. His mouth may be open.

A nude male figure with short, curly hair is pictured below and to the right of the multi-headed dragon. The figure's body faces forward with his head turned to the left and slightly upward. The figure's mouth is slightly open, and his expression suggests fear. Scales cover the figure's genitals, upper thighs, and lower abdomen. The figure crouches with his right leg bent and his left leg extended below and to the left. His right arm is bent behind his back with his right palm held vertically at his side and the fingers slightly spread. His left arm is raised at 135 degrees and he points upward with his left hand and index finger.

Below the multi-headed dragon, a nude male is seen from behind. He kneels on his right leg (his left is not pictured). His left arm is bent and he leans his left elbow on the rock to the left. His right arm is raised vertically (with respect to his body) with his palm up and his fingers spread. His head is seen in right profile, bent back and facing up.

Below and to the left of the multi-headed dragon, a bald, nude male sits with his left leg drawn up and his right leg extended below and to the right. The figures right elbow rests on the shield to the left. Both arms are bent and are loosely crossed in front of the figure's chest. His left hand may hold the hilt of the sword pictured to the left. The figure's body faces forward, but his head is bent back and faces up and to the right. His eyes might be closed.

Below and to the left of the bald figure, a sword and round shield rest on the rocks. The bald figure may hold the sword with his left hand. The shield is decorated with two lightning bolts terminating, at their lower ends, in arrow or spear points.
To the left of the bald figure is the head, upper body, and right hand of a (smiling?) male figure. He has short hair and holds a dagger in his right hand.
Above the smiling figure is an old male figure with long hair and a beard. His right arm is raised vertically and he holds a small bag of coins above his head. His expression suggests despair.
Above the figure of the old male is a female(?) head with long hair. She may be looking to the right.
Above the old male's raised hand is another head with long hair, facing forward.

To the left of the multi-headed dragon, an old(?) female sits with her legs drawn up. She is partly nude; her breasts are exposed and a skirt or gown (or drapery of some sort) covers her legs. Her legs are crossed at the ankles with her right foot prominent. Both arms are bent and her hands may clutch the sides of her head. Her left arm is bent upward and wraps around her head. Her right elbow may rest on the rock to the left. Her body faces forward with her head bent back and facing right. She appears to look up towards the Nativity scene above.
To the right of the old woman is the head and upper body of a nude female. Scaled cover her torso below her breasts. She has long hair and her mouth may be slightly open.
A head with only its eyes and nose visible appears to the right of the old woman, just above the female figure with scales.

desc.objtitle: The Overthrow of Apollo and the Pagan Gods, Object 4 (Butlin 538.4)

objnote.p: There are slight indications of an inscription, possibly Blake's signature and a date, just above the lower left margin. All but the tops of a few letters or numbers appear to have been trimmed off the sheet.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the design, the spirit of Apollo flees from a statue at Christ's birth. The nude statue stands facing forward and holds a winding serpent with both hands. The serpent faces down with its mouth open and tongue extended. The statue stands on a plinth or altar. A fire with smoke burns below the statue. Apollo's spirit emanates from the statue surrounded by fire. He is upside down and seen from behind with his arms raised vertically (relative to his body) and reaching downward. His mouth is open and he may be howling. A large star (probably the star of Bethlehem) is pictured right of his left upper arm. A female priestess sits in a small cave below and to the right of the statue of Apollo. Her flame-like hair stands on end and her mouth is open; she may be howling. Her prominent knees are drawn up and her arms are bent upward and braced against the walls of the cave. Below the statue, three gowned female priestesses kneel with their heads down. The priestess to the left bends her arms above her head with her hands together as if in prayer. One of the prietesses to the right places her hands on the ground, palms down. Below and to the left of the statue are two male figures (lars and lemures). They both have long hair and beards. The figure to the left clutches his head with his hands. The figure to the right bends both arms and holds his hands with the palms facing out. He wears a crown of laurel (?) leaves. Both men wear an epression of fear or grief. A gowned female stands in the distance above these figures. Above her is a stormy seascape. A ship, or possibly two ships, sink into the waves with two sails visible. To the right of the statue of Apollo, a spirit rises in flames from a statue near a group of four figures. The spirit has one leg drawn up and one arm raised vertically and the other at 135 degrees. To the right of the statue stands a gowned figure. He or she is twisted to the left and holds a stick or wand. Two female figures (one gowned, one gowned or possibly nude) stand to the left of the statue. A fourth nude figure lunges to the left with its right leg extended backward and its arms bent and raised in front of its body with the palms held vertically. A series of pillars topped with a lintel (possibly a colonnade or part of a temple) is shown to the left and right of the statue of Apollo. Four spirits fly or hover in the clouds at the top of the design. They fly toward the left with their bodies horiontal. The figure third from the left has the head of a cow, bull or ox and may represent Osiris or Moloch. The figure fourth from the left has the head of a dog and may represent Anubis. His head is turned to the right with his mouth open and toungue extended. He holds an indeterminate object, possibly a pitcher, in his left hand. Below the cow- and dog-headed figures is a winged circle or globe (the sun?) surrounded by two serpents with mouths open and tongues extended.

component.illusobjdesc: A statue of Apollo stands in the center of the design. The statue is nude and faces forward with its genitals exposed. The statue has curly hair. The statue's right arm is down at its side while its left is raised horizontally. The figure grasps a long, winding serpent or snake with both hands. The serpent's head is down with its mouth open and tongue extended. The figure of Apollo looks to the right at the serpent.
The statue stands on a plinth or altar probably made of stone.
A fire with smoke burns on the plinth or altar below the statue of Apollo.

The spirit of Apollo appears left of the statue. He is nude and is seen from behind. The figure is upside down and bends or twists left as he flees the statue. The figure's legs are together with his left leg bent and extended backward at the knee. Both arms are raised vertically (with respect to his body) and extend or reach downward. The fingers on both hands are spread. The figure has curly hair and his mouth is open; he may be howling. The figure is surrounded by tongues of flame that extend from the head and shoulders of the statue.
A single star with beams of light and a halo of radiance—likely the Star of Bethlehem—is pictured to the left of the statue of Apollo.

A priestess sits in a small cave below and to the right of the statue of Apollo. The figure is partly nude and wears only a skirt or other drapery on her lower body. Her long, flame-like hair stands on end and her mouth is open; she may be howling. She appears to look toward the statue to the left. She sits with her legs drawn up and her knees prominent. Both arms are bent upward and are braced against the walls of the cave.
The female priestess sits on a small table or stool.
The priestess sits in a small cave or alcove probably made of rock.

Below the statue of Apollo is a group of three female priestesses. All three are gowned and have long hair. They kneel on the ground with their heads down as if in prayer or supplication. One priestess kneels to the left of the statue and faces right. Her arms are bent with her hands raised and held together in prayer. Two priestesses kneel to the right of the statue facing left. The priestess closer to the viewer has her arms bent with her hands resting palms down on the ground. Her companion is partially obscured.

Below and to the left of the statue of Apollo is a group of two male figures, possibly the moaning lars and lemures of Milton's poem. Both figures are old and gowned with long hair and beards. They may be sitting or kneeling. The figure to the left bends his right arm and clutches his head with his right hand; his left arm is not pictured, but his left arm may also be grasping his head. The figure to the right bends both arms upward and has his hands raised with the palms out. He wears a crown of laurel (?) leaves on his head. Both figures look up and to the right toward the statue and wear expressions of fear or despair.
Two columns supporting a lintel are pictured above the two male figures.

A gowned female is seen standing (fleeing?) in the distance above the two male figures. Her body appears to face right, but her head is turned back to the left. Both arms are bent and raised in front of her body.
A stormy sea with waves is pictured to the left of the statue of Apollo. A ship, or possibly two ships, sink in the water with two sails visible.
A statue is seen in the distance to the right of the statue of Apollo. It appears to wear a cloak or gown.
The rectangular object left of the statue may be an altar of stone.

A (nude?) spirit surrounded by flames rises from this second statue. One arm is raised vertically, the other at 135 degrees, with its right (?) arm slightly bent. The figure's right leg is drawn up and its left leg is extended.
A gowned figure stands (or runs in flight?) to the right of the unidentified statue. The figure appears to twist to the left and may hold a stick or wand in one hand.

Two female figures stand to the left of the unidentified statue. The figure on the left may be nude and bends left with at least one arm (her right) bent upward. The figure to the right is gowned and may lean or kneel on the altar or stone.

A nude figure is seen from behind to the left of the unidentified statue. The figure lunges to the left with his legs spread; his left leg is bent and his right leg is extended backwards. At least his left arm is bent. His right arm is not pictured, but there is the indication that both hands are raised in front of the figure, palms held vertically. His body faces left, but his head is turned back to the right, as if looking toward the statue.
To the left of the unidentified statue is a structure—possibly a temple—composed of three visible pillars supporting a lintel.
The temple stands on hill forming a cliff descending into the sea on the left. Coloring on the ground suggests grass.

Across the top of the design is a group of four spirits flying or hovering in the clouds. They may be fleeing. The figure furthest left flies to the left with his or her legs together and both legs bent. The second figure from the left appears to be gowned with long hair and beard. His body is horizontal and one arm is extended to the left. The third figure from the left has the head of a cow, bull, or ox and may represent Osiris or Moloch. His or her head is turned facing right. The fourth figure from the left has the head of a dog and may represent Anubis. The figure's head is turned facing right with its mouth open and tongue extended. His right arm is extended to the left and his left arm is extended to the right. He may hold an indeterminate object, possibly a pitcher, in his right hand.

Below the cow- and dog-headed spirits is a winged circle or globe surrounded by two serpents facing left with mouths open and tongues extended. Flames (possibly suggesting the sun) or bolts of lightning are visible below the circle or globe.
Dark clouds are pictured across the top of the design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: At the top of the design, the spirit of Moloch is seen fleeing his statue below. The figure is seen from behind and flies on outstretched arms from which extend bat-like wings. The figure is nude and his bald head rests on his right shoulder. His legs are bent with the soles of his feet turned out towards the viewer. His left arm is raised horizontally and his right is raised at 135 degrees. Below is an altar to Moloch composed of a large furnace (constructed like a building) and a statue of Moloch with three infants. Fire erupts from openings in the furnace and also rise to the left and right of the statue. Smoke rises from the fire and fills the sky to the left and right of the fleeing spirit. The statue of Moloch is depicted as a king; he wears scaly armor and a crown and holds a scepter topped with a fleur-de-lis in his left hand. He is bearded. The figure sits on the furnace with left leg drawn up and his left foot prominent. His right arm is down at his side. In his right hand he holds an upside down infant by its right leg. The infant's arms are raised verticaly over its head and its left leg is bent. Two other infants are seen from behind near Moloch's left leg. The infant to the left climbs upward with its arms raised vertically. The infant to the right kneels facing left with its left arm raised vertically. Below the statue, a nude male infant stands on the altar in front of one of the furnace openings. His arms are raised vertically. The child may be a victim sacrificed to Moloch or he may represent the infant Christ. Two figures, one male and one female, kneel to the left and right of the infant, respectively. They may be the child's parents. The male bends or leans backward and rests his head on his right shoulder. His right arm is bent upward with the palm up and fingers spread. His left arm is raised horizontally and he touches or pushes the infant with his left hand. His mouth is open and he wears an expression of grief or despair. The female figure twists or bends backward with her head down. Her left arm is bent upward with the palm held vertically. Her right arm is raised horizontally and she touches or pushes the infant with her right hand. A group of gowned females stands to the left of the altar. Their arms are raised vertically and they hold and play trumpets, cymbals, and possibly tambourines and cymbals. The figures are seen from behind. The figure closest to the viewer strides with her legs crossed and her left leg extended backward. She and the other figures may be dancing. A group of figures stand to the right of the altar and also hold and play cymbals, a single trumpet, and at least one tambourine. The figure closest to the viewer is a gowned male with a long beard. His mouth is open and he may be singing. Mountains appear in the background left and right of the statue of Moloch. Dark wash at the top of the design suggests a night sky.

component.illusobjdesc: At the top of the design, the spirit of Moloch is seen fleeing his statue and altar below. The figure is seen from behind and flies on outstretched arms to which are attached bat-like wings. The figure is nude and his bald head rests on his right shoulder. His legs are bent with the soles of his feet turned out towards the viewer. His left arm is raised horizontally and his right is raised at 135 degrees (in relation to his body). His body leans or twists to the right.

Below Moloch's fleeing spirit is an altar to Moloch composed of a large iron furnace and a statue of Moloch with three infants. Fire erupts from the three openings in the furnace and also rise to the left and right of the statue. Smoke rises from the fire and fills the sky to the left and right of the fleeing spirit. The statue of Moloch is depicted as a king; he wears scaly armor and a crown and holds a scepter topped with a fleur-de-lis in his left hand. He is bearded and has short (possibly curly?) hair. He faces forward. The figure sits on the furnace with left leg drawn up and his left foot prominent. His left arm is bent and rests on his left leg. His right arm is down at his side. In his right hand he holds an upside down infant by its left leg. The infant's arms are raised verticaly over its head and its right leg is bent; the infant may be dead or dying. Two other infants are seen from behind near Moloch's left leg. The infant to the left climbs upward with its arms raised vertically. The infant to the right kneels facing left with its left arm raised vertically. The furnace is constructed like a building and even suggests the structure of a church with a crossing pattern of nave and transept. The openings have pointed arches. There may be a stool or table below the Moloch's left foot. The furnace stands on a large, circular plinth.

A nude male infant stands below the statue of Moloch, in front of (and possibly just emerging from) an opening to the furnace. The infant's genitals are clearly visible. His arms are raised vertically with the palms out and up and fingers slightly spread. The infant faces forward and may stride or walk forward with his left leg leading. He has short curly hair and his mouth is open. The infant may be a victim sacrificed to Moloch or he may possibly represent Christ.

A gowned male with short hair kneels to the left of the infant. His left arm is raised horizontally and he touches or pushes the infant with his left hand. He may be the child's father. The figure leans or bends backward. His body faces forward and to the right with his head turned away and resting on his left shoulder. His right arm is bent upward with the palm up and out and fingers spread. The figure's mouth is open and he wears an expression of grief or despair. His right foot is prominent. The figure casts a shadow to the left.

A gowned female with very long hair kneels to the right of the infant. Her right arm is raised horizontally and she touches or pushes the infant towards the flames with her right hand. She may be the child's mother. The figure faces left, but twists or bends backward and to the right. Her left arm is bent upward with the hand raised and palm held vertically. The figure has her head down. Her body language and facial expression, with mouth open, suggest grief or despair. The figure casts a shadow to the right.

A group of gowned females stand to the left of the altar. The figures are seen from behind with their arms raised vertically. The figures hold and play several instruments: trumpets, cymbals, and possibly tambourines. The figure closest to the viewer strides with her legs crossed and her left leg extended backward. She casts a shadow to the left. She and the other figures may be dancing.

A group of gowned figures stand to the right of the altar. The figures face forward and have their arms raised vertically. They hold and play several instruments: a single trumpet, cymbals, and at least one tambourine. The figure closest to the viewer is male and has a long beard. His mouth is open; he may be singing. He casts a shadow to the right. The figure above and to the left of the bearded male may have his head bent back while playing the trumpet.
Mountains appear in the background left and right of the statue of Moloch.
The foreground figures stand or kneel on a floor probably made of stone blocks.
Dark wash at the top of the design—particularly in the top left corner—suggests a night sky.

lg.l: WBlake 18The inscription, particularly the date (presumably "1809"), is partly trimmed off the sheet.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The stable stands in the lower two-thirds of the design. Grass covers the ground below the stable. Through an archway we see the Virgin Mary partly sitting and partly reclining on a large bed of straw. She is gowned and wears a cloth mantle or scraf over her long hair. Her legs are bent and she rests in a kneeling position. Her left arm rests at her side and her right arm is bent upward with her right hand supporting her head. Her eyes are closed and she may be sleeping. To the left of Mary, the infant Christ lies supine on top of the manger. His body is horizontal with his head to the left. His arms are crossed and rest on his chest. A halo with beams of light surrounds his head. Joseph stands above and to the right of Mary. He is gowned and wears a cloth or shawl over his short, curly hair. He has a beard. He stands facing left and bends forward, resting his crossed arms on the bed of straw. He appears to look toward Mary and the infant Christ. Two horned cows or bulls or oxen are pictured in the stable to the left of Mary. Four winged angels flank the arch of the stable. To the left, a male angel with long hair and a beard stands facing left. He may be wearing armor and a helmet. His left arm is bent and he holds a spear. Below this figure, an angel with long hair kneels with his (?) left leg drawn up and foot visible. He is gowned and wears a helmet. His left arm is bent and both hands hold the hilt of a sword. This fingers on his right hand are spread. To the right of the stable, a male angel with long hair and a beard stands facing right. He wears armor and a helmet. His right arm is bent and there are indications of a spear tip (partly trimmed off by the right margin of the design) above and to the right of his head. Though not pictured, he may hold this spear with his right hand. Below this figure, a male angel kneels or sits with his right leg drawn up and foot visible. He is gowned and wears a helmet, possibly decorated with feathers. His right arm is bent and rests on his right leg. He grasps the blade of a sword with his right hand. His left hand holds the hilt of the sword with the fingers spread. Two winged, gowned angels fly or hover above the stable. The angel on the left may be female. She has long hair and holds or plays a harp with her left hand. The angel to the right has long hair and may face away from the viewer. He or she also holds or plays a harp. Between the two angels, a woman in a chariot (a personification of the star of Bethlehem) and two horses rest on a cloud. The horses lie facing left with their heads turned to the right. Their front legs are bent and folded beneath them. The woman in the chariot is gowned. Her left arm is at her side while her right arm is bent and rests on the edge of the chariot. In her right hand she holds a luminous object, probably an oil lamp with a flame or a star above it. Other stars, perhaps eighteen in all, suggest a night sky.

component.illusobjdesc: The stable stands in the lower two-thirds of the design. The base appears to be made of wood while the roof, extending to the left and right, is thatched straw. A large archway, with decorative pointed arches, is at the center of the design. Through the archway the interior of the stable is shown with several posts and beams.

In the center of the design, the Virgin Mary half sits and half reclines in a kneeling posture on a bed of straw. She is gowned and wears a cloth mantle or scarf over her long hair. Her legs are bent and extend to the right. Her left arm rests at her side and her right arm is bent upward. Her head rests on her right hand. Her eyes are closed and she may be sleeping.

The infant Christ lies supine on a bundle of cloth or a pillow, which in turn rests on a bed of straw above the manger to the left of the Virgin Mary. The child is gowned and has his arms crossed and resting on his chest. His eyes are closed; he may be sleeping. A halo of radiance with beams of light emanate from Christ's head.
The infant Christ lies on a bed of a straw on top of a manger. A large bed of straw—which Mary rests on—covers the floor of the stable.

Joseph stands above and to the right of the Virgin Mary. He is gowned and wears a cloth or shawl over his curly hair. He is bearded. He bends forward, facing left, and leans on the bed of straw with his arms bent and crossed. He appears to be looking down at Mary and the infant Christ.
To the left of the Virgin Mary are two cows or bulls or oxen with horns. Only the tops of their heads and eyes are visible.

A winged male angel stands to the left of the arch, facing left. He has long hair and a beard. His eyes are down. He probably wears armor and a helmet. His left arm is bent. The upper shaft and tip of a spear appear above his head. Though not pictured, he may hold this spear with his left hand.

A winged angel kneels to the left of the arch with his left leg drawn up and left foot prominent. The angel's gender is uncertain. The figure is gowned and wears a helmet (possibly decorated with feathers) over his long hair. The figure's left arm is bent and he holds the hilt of a sword with both hands. The fingers on his right hand are spread.

A winged male angel stands to the right of the arch, facing right. He has long hair and a beard. He wears armor and may wear a helmet. There are indications of the tip of a spear (partly cut off by the right margin of the design) above his head. His right arm is bent. Though not pictured, he may hold the spear in his right hand.

A winged angel kneels or sits to the right of the stable, facing forward. He is gowned and wears a helmet, possibly decorated with feathers. His right leg is drawn up with the right foot visible. His right arm is bent and rests on his right leg. His right hand grasps (or at least touches) the blade of a sword while his left hand holds the hilt, fingers spread.
The ground below the stable is covered with grass.

Above and to the left of the stable, a winged female angel flies or hovers facing left. She is gowned and has long hair. Her left arm is bent and she holds and plays a harp. The figure may be smiling.

Above and to the right of the stable, a winged angel of indeterminate gender flies of hovers facing left. The figure is gowned and appears to have long hair. The figure's head may be turned away from the viewer. His or her right arm is bent. The figure holds and plays a harp.

At the top of the design, a gowned female (the personification of the star of Bethlehem) with long hair sits in a chariot. Her head is turned and faces slightly to the right. Her left arm is pictured at her side. Her right arm is bent and may rest on the edge of the chariot. In her right hand she holds an oil lamp with a flame or star above it. She may be smiling.
The female figure in the chariot holds an oil lamp in her right hand with a flame or star (probably the star of Bethlehem) above it. Beams of light emanate from the flame or star.
The female figure holding a lamp sits in a chariot with a single spoked wheel visible.

Two horses lie resting on a cloud to the left of the chariot. The horses' bodies face left with their heads turned back toward the right. Their front legs are bent and folded beneath them. Both horses have tails that extend to the right.
Clouds appear in the sky to the left and right of the flying angels and below the horses and chariot. Stars, perhaps eighteen in all, suggest a night scene.
